subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] On the Unicode proposal
msgSnippet: It would be possible to create a senior quikscript block, but I don t quite see why. If you re thinking about alternative and half letters then I d say that
messageBody:
It would be possible to create a senior quikscript block, but I don't
quite see why.
If you're thinking about alternative and half letters then I'd say that
those should be handled by the font layer since they depend on the chars
which surround them.
Arabic and Thai scripts work this way, Arabic in particular has very
similar problems choosing glyphs.

Of course if you're thinking of something else then ignore what I just
said :)

Timothy Rice wrote:
> Glad I was able to clear up some of your doubts.
> In the Unicode block for Shavian (available at unicode.org in PDF
> format) the letters Roar and Nun are sandwiched between the letters Ah
> and Eat, quite misleading. Also, there is no namer dot, which leads to
> further confusion on the true function of the middle dot. One source
> on Shavian said that an asterik can also be used as a namer dot, but
> it is the only source that I have seen say that so far.
> Would it be possible to follow the example of complex scripts like
> Devanagari or Tibetan and make a Senior Quickscript block?
>
> */amd64_hacker <amd64_hacker@...>/* wrote:
>
> Thanks for clearing up the middle dot thing - that was bugging me all
> last night :)
>
> I've just taken another glance at shavian, we should probably note the
> similarities (ie ing and hung) between the two scripts in our
> proposal.
>
> How do you feel the mapping should go, you mentioned errors in shavian
> which you wanted to avoid?
>
> Timothy Rice wrote:
> > Thank you for responding,
> > perhaps you are right about the middle dot not functioning as a
> > namer dot. Early Shavian proposals had an extra character that was
> > replaced in the current block by the middle dot, though Unicode is
> > good about assigning individual characters to every function. Latin
> > capital letter a, Cyrillic capital letter a and Greek capital letter
> > alpha all look the same in most typefaces. An even better example is
> > the Runic letters Ansuz A and Runic letter Aesc. Same glyph,
> different
> > uses.
> > On a different note, the middle dot is used in mathematics to
> > indicate multiplication where the traditional multiplication
> sign can
> > be confused with variable X.
> > */amd64_hacker <amd64_hacker@...
> <mailto:amd64_hacker%40yahoo.co.uk>>/* wrote:
> >
> > Hi,
> >
> > Glad you could join the group, welcome :)
> >
> > There are several ways of looking at the mapping.
> > I feel that the chars should be mapped linearly in the order
> that they
> > are in in the quikscript manual.
> > It simplifies things for everyone since the char you want is qs
> > unicode
> > block + number in the qs manual.
> > Kinda like how A (letter 1) is 65 and Z (26) is 90, it'd be
> > unintuitive
> > if they were in any other order.
> > But there are other orderings which can be chosen which have other
> > benefits.
> > I'd say this is the right place to debate their merits :)
> >
> > I have to disagree with you on you on the middle dot though, it's
> > not a
> > naming dot, it's a middle dot, they look identical but they mean
> > different things (actually, does anyone here know what a middle dot
> > means? I've never used it or seen it used).
> > It'd probably be worth noting the similarity on the proposal,
> unicode
> > has approximate and equivalent representations noted for each
> char so
> > that a suitable substitution can be made if the char isn't
> > available in
> > the current font.
> > But that's just my feeling on the matter, I do a lot more
> > processing of
> > data than looking at it so I just like having that extra
> information.
> >
> > Anyway - welcome to the group again :)
> >
> > tim_rice09 wrote:
> > >
> > > Adding the Read Alphabet to Unicode is a very good idea. The
> > > Shavian encoding serves as a good example though some errors in it
> > > should be avoided. For example consonants encoded among vowels and
> > > rather unnapealing letter names should not be present in the
> > > Quickscript block. Also the middle dot (Unicode 00B7) could be
> used
> > > for the namer dot.
> > >
> > >
> >
> >
> > __________________________________________________________
